title: Rugby World Cup 2019 live: Australia vs Uruguay
text:
Australia scored four tries in 22 minutes in an explosive start to the second half, but none of the five-pointers were celebrated like the madness that followed James Slipper's first ever try for Australia.

Slipper barged over in the second half to score his first ever test try, a feat that took him 94 international appearances to achieve.

His 94-match wait is the second longest try drought in test rugby, just 14 short of Kiwi Owen Franks' record of 108 tests before his first try.

Slipper's try created mad scenes on the field as Wallabies teammates came from everywhere to congratulate the prop forward and jump all over him.

It was interchange prop Taniela Tupou who delivered the most eye-catching celebration, calmly walking up to Slipper after his teammates broke away from a celebration pile-on and plonked a kiss on his teammates' cheek.

"He got a kiss from Taniela Tupou just there," Gordon Bray told Channel 10.

"That's how tight the front rowers are. Taniela Tupou gave him a big smooch on the cheek.

"They're a different breed."

Slice of wholesome content for your Saturday.



James Slipper is finally over!



Every Match, Every Nation of the #RWC2019 on Fox Sports pic.twitter.com/nt37imwRuO — FOX SPORTS Rugby (@FOXRUGBY) October 5, 2019 https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js

The try took Australia to a 45-3 lead before Uruguay scored a late consolation try in the 78th minute – the country's first ever try against a tier one rugby nation at the World Cup.

Slipper's drought-breaking try was one of many moments that gave stressed coach Michael Cheika reason to smile.

Teenager Jordan Petaia starred on debut while winger Dane Haylett-Petty and outside centre Tevita Kuridrani both bagged doubles.

Pin. Point. Precise.



A brilliant set piece from the @wallabies and the Train is through again for his second try! 🚂



🇦🇺 26-3 🇺🇾 #AUSvURU #RWC2019 pic.twitter.com/ut8vXOAomi — 10 Sport (@10SportAU) October 5, 2019 https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js

Winger Petaia crossed with his second touch as Australia ran in seven tries to one in humid conditions in Oita.

The performance was marred by first-half yellow cards shown to forwards Adam Coleman and Lukhan Salakaia-Loto, both for high tackles.

French referee Mathieu Raynal brandished his first yellow card when deeming Coleman had tackled fullback Rodrigo Silva around the shoulder.

That 14th minute infringement was followed 15 minutes later by a near-identical indiscretion from flanker Salakaia-Loto. Neither incident looked bad enough to earn a citing but both players will be nervous after lazy efforts.

Other Australian high shots were also penalised in a concerning lack of discipline from Cheika’s team, who were punished by match officials for similar offences in the opening win over Fiji and the loss to Wales.

A 12-5 penalty count against them is a headache Cheika must address ahead of Friday’s final pool clash with Georgia.

Cheika, however, was much more concerned with his team's slow start than his team's poor discipline.

“I thought we were just a little bit off the pace at the start,” Cheika conceded.

“That’s three times now, three games a little bit off the pace at the start — I’ll have to get my pre-match speech a little bit better.

“We were in it in the first half nicely, but it looked like were just a click away and then we got the pace up in the second half.

“But like I said before the match, the (Uruguayan) guys are big hearted and they take it to you and they’ve obviously improved since the last World Cup, and I think we’ve seen that directly because we’ve played them.”

The bonus point win means Australia have virtually locked down a quarter-final berth, with only a series of upsets able to deny them.

The remain on track to finish second in pool D but could yet claim top spot if Fiji upset Wales in Oita on Wednesday.

Petaia was the brightest element to emerge from Australia’s win.

The 19-year-old had limited opportunities but displayed a good work effort to secure his try and backed that up with a thrilling assist to Kuridrani in which he slid past three defenders and threw a memorable assist.

Australia’s youngest player at the World Cup, Petaia made way at halftime in a pre-planned substitution.

The Wallabies went to another gear in the second spell, crossing four times against the 18th-ranked South Americans, who nevertheless had the final say through a try to No. 8 Manuel Diana.

– with AAP
